I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  discussions  on  the  country  operations  business  plan  for  Mongolia,  the 
Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB), for technical assistance (TA) for Policy 
and Institutional Support for Banking Sector Systemic Risk Management. A fact-finding mission 
visited Ulaanbaatar from 29 July to 4 August 2009, and an understanding was reached with the 
Government on the TA objectives, scope, terms of reference, cost estimates, financing plan, 
and implementation arrangements. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Banking Crisis. Mongolia has been hit by a combination of worsening terms of trade 
due to a fall in copper prices, and subsequent rapid slowdown of domestic growth. Gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to slow markedly from 9% last year to 0.3% in 2009. 
Because of this economic downturn, the banking sector in Mongolia is heading for a systemic 
crisis.2 The sector’s nonperforming loan (NPL) ratio, including past due loans, is reported to be 
more than 19% for July 2009, up from 5% in June 2008 (Table 1); and is expected to reach 30% 
by the end of this year.3 Total outstanding loans declined by 6% in nominal terms between 
September 2008 and June 2009, although inflation was in double digits during most of this 
period.

3.  Several small- and medium-sized banks are also suffering from weak internal controls 
and poor corporate governance. Off-balance sheet transactions and contingent liabilities may 
pose additional threats and several Mongolian banks have persistent problems with fraudulent 
letters of credit. Of the 15 commercial banks, 3 are large, 7 are medium-sized, and 5 are small. 
All banks are privately owned and autonomous, with no government involvement in policy-
making, management, and operations. 
 
4.  Fiscal Impact. The Government’s actions thus far reflect ad-hoc emergency efforts, 
such as the establishment of the blanket deposit guarantee and emergency liquidity injections 
into commercial banks by the Bank of Mongolia (BOM), the central bank. The blanket deposit 
guarantee exposes the Government to considerable fiscal risk, as high as 70% of GDP. A 
recent  stress  test  conducted  by  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  indicates  that 
recapitalization needs to bring capital adequacy ratios above the BOM norm; the cost of this

could reach 10% of GDP. One recapitalization option being considered is the issuance of 
government restructuring bonds.4  
 
5.  Need for Swift Action. The Ministry of Finance and BOM have yet to decide on a 
comprehensive and consistent strategy and plan of actions to resolve the banking crisis. The 
above-mentioned ad-hoc measures may ease immediate pressure on banks and borrowers, but 
may  expose  the  Government  to  higher  fiscal  impact  and  provide  disincentives  that  may 
undermine market discipline and the sustainability of the banking system. The Government 
indicates that it would like to (i) act swiftly; (ii) minimize public financial support; (iii) reinvigorate 
the banking sector for it to lend again, especially to vulnerable industries; (iv) seek funding from 
international  financial  institutions  to  meet  the  recapitalization  needs  of  banks;  and  
(v)  attract  foreign  investors.  A  well  thought-out  and  swiftly  implemented  approach  is  a 
preemptive measure to address the banking crisis, in contrast to an ad-hoc approach that 
focuses on individual failed banks. Eventually, the ad-hoc approach is likely to incur higher fiscal 
costs while risking a bank run and collapse of the banking sector. 
 
6.  Nonperforming Loan Resolution. The proper disposal and management of impaired 
assets is one of the most critical and complex tasks in managing banking crises. International 
experiences from previous banking crises have shown mixed results for various approaches to 
NPL resolution and systemic risk management for banking. What has worked well in one 
country in a particular situation may not necessarily work in another. Nonetheless, ensuring that 
a coherent legal and regulatory environment and the market infrastructure necessary for the 
chosen NPL resolution approach are in place is important. 
 
7.  BOM  and  the  Government  should  consider  a  number  of  available  approaches  for 
different phases of a banking crisis.5 When the amount of impaired assets reaches systemic 
proportions, i.e., the majority of banks are technically insolvent, in-house collection to resolve 
NPLs becomes less effective as it requires more financial and human resources and thus forces 
commercial banks to move away from normal banking business. On the other hand, a "good 
bank" and "bad bank" approach would generally be considered appropriate during a banking 
crisis, where the "bad bank" can be an asset management company (AMC).  
 
8.  A multifaceted approach may be required to resolve NPLs in Mongolia, such as a 
combination  of  in-house  collection  and  AMC;  and  quick-disposal  and  long-term  corporate 
restructuring. However, regardless of the approach used, creditor rights and insolvency systems 
must be strengthened and formal restructuring and rehabilitation mechanisms improved.  
 
9.  An AMC generally has more flexibility in using different NPL resolution techniques, has 
more leverage over non-paying borrowers from consolidating their debts from different banks, 
and  can  serve  as  a  vehicle  for  the  orderly  restructuring  of  certain  economic  sectors. 
Nonetheless, the success of AMCs in developing countries has been hindered by a number of 
factors such as a large portion of nonperforming policy loans, the presence of political influence, 
and the lack of appropriate funding and professional management. Studies indicate that for 
AMCs to be successful, they need to have assets that are easily liquidated, operate without 
political interference, have no loans to state-owned enterprises, and operate in a well-developed 
legal and institutional environment.   
                                                 
4  IMF earlier endorsed the blanket deposit guarantee and indicated that the principal of restructuring bonds will not 
be counted as part of the current government budget deficit and thus be excluded from the IMF Standby 
Agreement. The interest payments will be included in the budget deficit calculation. 
5  Measures during the containment phase could include deposit freeze, bank holiday, blanket guarantee, liquidity 
support, and emergency lending. Measures during the resolution phase could include forbearance, large-scale 
government intervention, bank closure, nationalization, mergers, sales to foreigners, banking restructuring agency, 
asset management company, recapitalization, deposit insurance, and haircuts (including on depositors).

3
 
10.    The new AMC in Mongolia, if needed, must be a separate legal and independent entity 
insulated from political influence, with the Government not being involved in its day-to-day 
operations  and  management  decisions.  It  needs  to  be  managed  professionally  and  have 
significant expertise in asset management and NPL resolution. The success of the AMC will 
depend upon its having strong leadership, proper governance structures and internal controls, 
operating independence, and appropriately structured incentives to its employees to maximize 
recovery rates resulting from the disposition of the impaired assets.  
 
11.  Capacity Building. Due to the limited human resources available in Mongolia, capacity-
building initiatives in NPL resolution and corporate governance should be provided to the AMC 
management and staff, the AMC supervisory and regulatory agencies, the commercial banks, 
and selected specialists from the legal and judicial system. Operating support for the AMC 
should  be  provided  through  the  engagement  of  long-term  advisory  and/or  management 
consultants. In addition, judges should be trained on new issues pertaining to such areas as 
receivership, bankruptcy, corporate and banking law, and NPL resolution.  
 
12.  Legal and Regulatory Framework. Effective systemic risk management of the banking 
system requires a supportive legal and regulatory framework. The Central Bank Law and the 
Banking Law do not provide enough legal support for BOM in some areas, such as consolidated 
supervision and supervision for connected party lending; they also do not provide sufficient legal 
protection for BOM supervisors. Moreover, the lack of an effective framework for nonjudicial 
foreclosure is a key impediment to the rapid resolution of NPLs. Special legislation will also be 
needed for speedy bankruptcy processes, and NPL transfer and recovery. 
 
13.  Corporate Governance and Internal Controls. Weak corporate governance structures 
and internal controls plague the Mongolian banking system; capacity to address operations 
issues is often insufficient. Significant risks are inadequately identified, measured, monitored, or 
controlled. Fraudulent letters of credit, excessive concentration of lending to connected parties, 
the  rescheduling  of  NPLs  to  avoid  proper  classification  and  provisioning,  and  outright 
malfeasance have all contributed to the weak condition of many commercial banks.  
 
14.  ADB has provided considerable support to the transformation of Mongolia’s finance 
sector since 1991.6 This support will continue in the form of TA on NPL resolution; strengthening 
of  BOM  capacity;  and  later,  strengthening  of  a  deposit  insurance  system.  It  is  part  of  a 
coordinated development partner effort to help BOM and the Government better manage the 
banking crisis. Under this effort, the International Finance Corporation and European Bank for 
Reconstruction and Development will focus on assisting their client banks. The United States 
Agency for International Development will be dealing with case-by-case workouts of troubled 
banks and on training bank staff in credit underwriting. ADB, IMF and the World Bank will jointly 
work on policy actions for systemic risk management and restructuring of the banking sector. 
IMF is conducting a first estimate (ahead of the diagnostic portfolio audits) of the potential fiscal 
cost of restructuring the banking sector, and the World Bank will conduct portfolio audits for 
most commercial banks. The United States Treasury is planning to field a long-term advisor to 
BOM on problem bank resolution. The Japan International Cooperation Agency is supporting 
BOM's Banking Supervision Department by preparing an inspection manual and evaluation 
model for corporate governance, and a manual for information technology inspections. 
 
 
                                                 
6  The   2008   Country  Assistance  Program Evaluation (CAPE) rated ADB's  support  to  the  financial  sector  as 
successful and relevant.

4  
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
15.  The expected impact of the TA is a stronger and broader-based economic recovery 
supported  by  a  healthy  banking  sector.  The  expected  outcome  is  the  establishment  of  a 
conducive  and  prudent  policy  and  operating  framework  for  systemic  risk  management  of 
banking sector and distressed assets resolution.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
16.  The TA will deliver four major outputs: 
 
(i)  Reinforce BOM and Government leadership, authority, and capacity in systemic 
risk management of banking sector by (a) developing an NPL resolution action 
plan;  (b)  reviewing  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  banking  sector 
systemic  risk  management  and  NPL  resolution  and  supervision,  and  by 
suggesting amendments; and (c) developing special legislation, if needed, for the 
implementation of the chosen NPL resolution approach, as well as supporting 
action  and  assistance  in  meeting  legal  and  regulatory  requirements  for 
implementing this approach. 
(ii)  Strengthen the corporate governance and internal controls of commercial banks 
by (a) developing guidelines for corporate governance reforms and improvements 
in risk management, and internal controls for commercial banks; (b) ensuring that 
stricter  standards  of  corporate  governance,  risk  management,  and  internal 
controls are enforced as an integral part of NPL resolution and commercial bank 
recapitalization;  and  (c)  raising  public  awareness  of  the  need  for  corporate 
governance  in  the  commercial  banking  sector  by  supporting  the  Corporate 
Governance Development Center at the Institute of Finance and Economics, 
which is indirectly associated with the Government. 
(iii)  Support a multifaceted approach for NPL resolution by (a) examining various 
approaches  to  NPL  resolution  and  recommending  a  best  combination;  (b) 
preparing implementation strategies using the best combination of approaches; (c) 
providing advice on all NPL resolution-related techniques and operations; and (d) 
providing  training  and  capacity  building  initiatives  in  essential  skills  for  NPL 
management and resolution.7 
(iv)  Provide  knowledge  products  in  the  forms  of  policy  and  technical  notes  and 
workshops targeting senior policy and decision makers.8 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $2,300,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $2,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government and BOM, the 
Executing Agency, will provide in-kind contributions worth $300,000. Detailed cost estimates 
and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
 
                                                 
7  Training activities include workshops and seminars, as well as on-the-job training by international consultants. 
8  Knowledge products can cover a range of topics such as a systemic risk management strategy for the banking 
sector, NPL resolution techniques, and corporate governance mechanisms.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  BOM, as the Executing Agency, will have overall responsibility for ensuring coordination 
with  other  government  agencies,  timely  project  implementation,  and  reporting  to  ADB  on 
progress made, problems encountered, and remedial actions taken during implementation. The 
AMC, if established, would be the Implementing Agency.  
 
19.  The TA will require the services of international consultants (up to 44 person-months) 
and national consultants (up to 88 person-months). Expertise in the following areas of work will 
be accessed: systemic risk management of the banking sector, legal and regulatory reform, 
corporate governance and internal control, distressed assets resolution, and NPL management. 
The outline terms of reference for the consulting services in those areas and the detailed 
breakdown of consultant allocations in each area are in Appendix 3. ADB will select and engage 
the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time).  
 
20.  The TA will use a mix of individual consultants and consulting firms, with more complex 
assignments being given to consulting firms to facilitate coordination of the inputs of the various 
experts. For an estimated budget of $800,000, three international consultants will be engaged 
on an individual basis9 for a total of 25 person-months and three national consultants for a total 
of 65 person-months. In the case of a firm, the preferred selection method for consultants is 
quality and cost-based selection with a quality-cost ratio of 80:20. The proceeds of the TA will 
be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.10 For  the 
procurement of equipment and the conduct of training seminars and conferences, an advance 
payment facility could be used.11 
 
21.  The TA is expected to begin in November 2009 and end in December 2012. The last  
3 months of this period are allocated for contract completion.  
 
22.  Individual consultants or consulting firms, once engaged, will submit the following to 
ADB and BOM: (i) an inception report 2 weeks after the commencement of their services, 
(ii) interim progress reports at appropriate stages during TA implementation, (iii) a draft final 
report before the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) a final report 2 weeks after receiving 
comments  from  ADB  and  BOM.  All  reports  will  be  submitted  in  English  and  Mongolian. 
Workshops will be organized periodically to disseminate the consultants’ findings and to discuss 
policy recommendations. Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by 
the BOM and ADB administration missions. Consultants’ reports will be presented at workshops 
and seminars organized for the validation of findings. Selected reports will be made available on 
ADB websites in English and Mongolian, if appropriate, and published whenever warranted.  
   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
23.     The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $2,000,000  on  a  grant  basis  to  Mongolia  for  Policy  and 
Institutional Support for Banking Sector Systemic Risk Management.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.     International and national consultants will be recruited to support implementation of 
various  aspects  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA).  The  consultants  should  possess  good 
knowledge of, and sufficient experience in, areas related to systemic risk management for 
banking sector in Mongolia and other countries. International consultants will be responsible for 
introducing international experiences and best practices, providing advisory services on key 
technical issues, disseminating lessons, and providing advice to policy makers, management 
assistance, and training of counterpart staff. National consultants will be recruited to assist the 
international  consulting  team,  provide  general  background  and  case  studies,  and  translate 
documents. 
 
2.     Consulting services are allocated for five areas (Table A3): (i) systemic risk management 
for  banking  sector,  (ii)  legal  and  regulatory  reform,  (iii)  corporate  governance  and  internal 
controls,  (iv)  distressed  assets  resolution  with  the  possibility  of  establishing  an  asset 
management company (AMC), and (v) nonperforming loan (NPL) management.   
 
A.  Systemic Risk Management for Banking Sector (consulting services: international, 3 
person-months; national, 12 person-months) 
 
3.     The specialists will work closely with the Bank of Mongolia (BOM), Ministry of Finance, 
and other government agencies to 
 
(i)  develop an NPL resolution strategy and action plan to systematically address the 
banking crisis; 
(ii)  provide support, in cooperation with other development partners, to the work-out 
unit at the Bank of Mongolia (BOM) in implementing a consistent and transparent 
approach to the management of the bank crisis; 
(iii)  provide  advice  within  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory  framework  on  the 
approach  for  the  resolution  of  NPLs,  transfer  of  ownership,  foreclosure  of 
collateral, bankruptcy, and court system procedures; 
(iv)  analyze operations issues for implementation of the NPL resolution approach, 
including various methods for the Government to finance the approach based on 
the size of the NPLs, maximizing asset recovery within a defined time and budget 
with which NPLs should be acquired; 
(v)  based on the outcomes of the portfolio audit of commercial banks, provide advice 
on how to establish the criteria for commercial banks to transfer NPLs; 
(vi)  identify financing strategies for NPL transfer; 
(vii)  recommend how the distressed asset resolution approach should address issues 
on  NPLs,  transfer  of  ownership,  foreclosure,  bankruptcy,  and  court  system 
procedures, within the existing legal and regulatory framework; 
(viii)  help prepare and review regulations to support implementation of the distressed 
asset resolution approach in Mongolia; 
(ix)  organize  workshops  and  training  sessions  for  regulatory  and  supervisory 
personnel  on  the  distressed  asset  resolution  approach,  as  well  as  BOM 
supervisory staff; and for selected judges in each of the district courts of the 
country pertaining to new issues in foreclosure and bankruptcy law, and civil and 
banking laws relevant to NPL resolution. 
 
B.  Legal and Regulatory Reform (consulting services: international, 5 person-months; 
national, 8 person-months)

4.     The specialists will work closely with BOM, Ministry of Finance, and other Government 
agencies to  
 
(i)  review and suggest amendments to the legislative and regulatory framework for 
systemic risk management for banking sector and NPL resolution including the 
Central Bank Law and Banking Law, paying special attention for provisions of 
proper supervisory authority to BOM and proper legal definition for connected 
parties lending; 
(ii)  review  the  Mortgage  Law  and  Mortgage-backed  Securities  Law  regarding 
provisions for nonjudicial foreclosure procedures; 
(iii)  review the legal, regulatory, and institutional framework related to different asset 
resolution  techniques,  particularly  regarding  orderly  transfer  of  ownership, 
management of weak assets, and bankruptcy; and propose amendments;  
(iv)  review and analyze options and assist in the drafting, preparation, and review of 
the  regulatory  framework  for  implementing  the  distressed  asset  resolution 
approach; 
(v)  support  BOM  in  improving  regulatory  approaches  to  deter  irregularities  and 
malpractices  in  commercial  banks  in  areas  that  include  a  risk-based  loan 
categorization system, trade finance risk management, and loan rescheduling; 
and  
(vi)  review  and  advise  on  the  current  legislative  and  regulative  framework  for 
corporate governance reforms for banking sector, in particular on provisions to 
enhance enforcement. 
 
C.  Corporate  Governance  and  Internal  Control  (consulting  services:  international,  
3 person-months; national, 6 person-months) 
 
5.     The  specialists  will  help  strengthen  corporate  governance  standards  and  risk 
management in commercial banks. They will 
 
(i)  assist  BOM  in  implementing  the  new  corporate  governance  guidelines  by 
participating in the inspection of selected commercial banks; 
(ii)  develop requirements for reforms of corporate governance, risk management, 
and internal controls in all banks committed to engaging in transactions with the 
AMC; 
(iii)  in  cooperation  with  the  BOM  Supervision  Department,  review  and  assess 
corporate  governance,  risk  management,  and  internal  control  plans  and 
safeguards  for  banks  from  which  AMC  is  purchasing  assets  at  the  time  of 
transaction, based on AMC requirements and BOM’s own corporate governance 
regulation; 
(iv)  assist the BOM Supervision Department in validating the corporate governance 
reforms of banks and ensure that stricter standards of corporate governance are 
enforced as an integral part of the NPL resolution and recapitalization process for 
commercial  banks  that  have  agreed  to  participate  in  the  distressed  asset 
resolution approach; 
(v)  increase public awareness of corporate governance issues in commercial banks 
and support the Corporate Governance Development Center at the Institute of 
Finance and Economics to assume the watchdog role and enhance its capacity; 
and

Appendix 3  11 
(vi)  develop  guidelines  for  risk  management,  internal  controls,  and  core  banking 
systems in all banks that wish to participate in the distressed asset resolution 
approach, covering, inter alia, accurate and timely recording of trade financing, 
proper  reporting  and  classification  of  all  restructured  loans,  and  accurate 
monitoring of connected party borrowing and deposits. 
 
D.  AMC Establishment and Management (consulting services: international 21 person-
months; national, 38 person-months; the team leader will be the international asset 
management specialist) 
 
6.     The specialists will work closely with BOM, Ministry of Finance, and the Government to 
 
(i)  advise the Government on the appropriate mandates for the AMC; 
(ii)  contribute to the drafting, preparation, and review of necessary legal documents, 
including  special  legislation,  for  implementing  the  distressed  asset  resolution 
approach;  
(iii)  assess possible ownership and operating structures for implementation of the 
distressed  asset  resolution  approach,  including  possible  private  sector 
shareholders,  and  recommend  a  prudent  governance  structure  including  the 
composition of the board of directors and various committees; 
(iv)  analyze operating issues for the distressed asset resolution approach, including 
various options for the Government to finance the approach based upon the size 
of the NPL loan portfolio and which NPLs should be acquired;  
(v)  identify a set of optimal and integrated strategies to support asset acquisition, 
valuation, and disposal in order to maximize the recovery value of NPLs within a 
finite time horizon and budget; 
(vi)  establish the management team once the distressed asset resolution approach is 
established and assemble the professional management team to implement the 
approach; 
(vii)  prepare a set of rules, guidelines, and procedures for various operating activities 
to implement the distressed asset resolution approach;  
(viii)  select  a  sample  of  cases  resolving  NPLs  in  different  sectors  and  formulate 
strategies for the provision of on-the-job learning opportunities for staff who will 
implement the distressed asset resolution approach;  
(ix)  compile a collection of cases of best practices to be used as case law for future 
court proceedings; and 
(x)  develop the blueprint, including specifications for the appropriate hardware and 
software  for  the  management  information  system  for  the  distressed  asset 
resolution  approach  to  ensure  adequate  security,  storage,  and  retrieval 
capabilities  to  enhance  implementation  of  the  approach,  and  internal  record 
management and external disclosure. 
 
7.      The international asset management specialist, as the team leader, will be responsible 
for managing knowledge products preparation; all consultants will contribute. 
 
E.  Nonperforming  Loan  Management  (consulting  services:  international,  12  person-
months; national 24 person-months) 
 
8.     The  specialists  will  assist  the  entity  implementing  the  distressed  asset  resolution 
approach  in  NPL  workouts  in  particular  sectors  (e.g.,  real  estate  and  mining)  in  order  to

maximize  recovery  rates,  and  strengthen  its  risk  management  and  financial  management 
capabilities. Specifically, the specialists will 
 
(i)  review, categorize, and prioritize the NPLs in construction, mining, and other 
sectors  with  large  NPL  concentration  to  maximize  recovery  rates  within  the 
defined time period; 
(ii)  formulate credit, interest rate, and foreign exchange risk management strategies, 
and the manuals and procedures to implement them; 
(iii)  formulate  policy  and  procedures  to  control  organizational,  operating,  and 
financial risks;  
(iv)  develop strategies for specialized NPL disposals, including debt–equity swaps, 
asset  securitization,  auctioning  of  specified  and  categorized  assets,  and 
individual offerings; and 
(v)  develop guidelines for accounting, and internal and external audit functionalities 
of the AMC.
